ISSUE_TITLE: Course #1: Include Lab(s) for SEARCH / SEARCH ALL for table handling in COBOL
ISSUE_TEXT:
As search is frequently performed on tables, this Lab would be a good inclusion to Course 1.
SEARCH verb - Serial search on unsorted tables
SEARCH ALL verb - Binary search on table sorted in some sequence.
We can have two COBOL programs, one for each of the cases above, with input record processing that relies on looking up values in a COBOL table (OCCURS clause with index).
COMMENT_TEXT:
I have these 2 COBOL code in mind for this, but in my opinion, it's a bit weird considering table handling is not something which is covered here. As a matter of fact, the only time tables are mentioned is on the paragraph detailing the SEARCH statements.
But then, adding table handling to Course 1 when it's already released on many different platforms seems counterproductive (my fear being those that took the course on the other platform might go here and say "Wait, why don't we have those on < put platform name here >?").
With that in mind, should we explore adding this to Course 2 instead?
Anyway, feedbacks are welcomed! CBLSRCH1 explores doing a SEARCH and CBLSRCH2 explores SEARCH ALL. Both codes uses the existing ZXXXXX.DATA so that we don't need to create any new dataset.
      *-----------------------
       IDENTIFICATION DIVISION.
      *-----------------------
       PROGRAM-ID.    CBLSRCH1
       AUTHOR.        Otto B. Boolean.
      *--------------------
       ENVIRONMENT DIVISION.
      *--------------------
       INPUT-OUTPUT SECTION.
       FILE-CONTROL.
           SELECT ACCT-REC   ASSIGN TO ACCTREC.
      *-------------
       DATA DIVISION.
      *-------------
       FILE SECTION.
       FD  ACCT-REC RECORDING MODE F.
       01  ACCT-FIELDS        PIC X(170).
      *
       WORKING-STORAGE SECTION.
       01  FLAGS.
           05  LASTREC            PIC X VALUE SPACE.
               88  END-OF-FILE          VALUE 'Y'.
           05  TABLE-VAR          PIC S9(4) COMP.
           05  TABLE-MAX          PIC S9(4) COMP VALUE 45.
      *
       01  ACCT-TABLE.
           05  ACCT-TABLE-ITEM OCCURS 45 TIMES INDEXED BY TABLE-IDX.
               10  ACCT-NO            PIC X(8).
               10  ACCT-LIMIT         PIC S9(7)V99 COMP-3.
               10  ACCT-BALANCE       PIC S9(7)V99 COMP-3.
               10  LAST-NAME          PIC X(20).
               10  FIRST-NAME         PIC X(15).
               10  CLIENT-ADDR.
                   15  STREET-ADDR    PIC X(25).
                   15  CITY-COUNTY    PIC X(20).
                   15  USA-STATE      PIC X(15).
               10  RESERVED           PIC X(7).
               10  COMMENTS           PIC X(50).
      *
      *------------------
       PROCEDURE DIVISION.
      *------------------
       OPEN-FILES.
           OPEN INPUT ACCT-REC.
      *
       LOAD-TABLES.
           PERFORM READ-RECORD.
           PERFORM VARYING TABLE-VAR FROM 1 BY 1
             UNTIL TABLE-VAR = TABLE-MAX OR END-OF-FILE
               MOVE ACCT-FIELDS TO ACCT-TABLE-ITEM (TABLE-VAR)
               PERFORM READ-RECORD
           END-PERFORM.
      *
       SEARCH-RECORD.
           SET TABLE-IDX TO 1.
           SEARCH ACCT-TABLE-ITEM VARYING TABLE-IDX
               AT END DISPLAY "Not Found"
               WHEN LAST-NAME (TABLE-IDX) = "ROOSEVELT"
                   DISPLAY "Roosevelt is found!".
      *
       CLOSE-STOP.
           CLOSE ACCT-REC.
           STOP RUN.
      *
       READ-RECORD.
           READ ACCT-REC
           AT END MOVE 'Y' TO LASTREC
           END-READ.
      *

and
      *-----------------------
       IDENTIFICATION DIVISION.
      *-----------------------
       PROGRAM-ID.    CBLSRCH2
       AUTHOR.        Otto B. Boolean.
      *--------------------
       ENVIRONMENT DIVISION.
      *--------------------
       INPUT-OUTPUT SECTION.
       FILE-CONTROL.
           SELECT ACCT-REC   ASSIGN TO ACCTREC.
      *-------------
       DATA DIVISION.
      *-------------
       FILE SECTION.
       FD  ACCT-REC RECORDING MODE F.
       01  ACCT-FIELDS        PIC X(170).
      *
       WORKING-STORAGE SECTION.
       01  FLAGS.
           05  LASTREC            PIC X VALUE SPACE.
               88  END-OF-FILE          VALUE 'Y'.
           05  TABLE-VAR          PIC S9(4) COMP.
           05  TABLE-MAX          PIC S9(4) COMP VALUE 45.
      *
       01  ACCT-TABLE.
           05  ACCT-TABLE-ITEM OCCURS 45 TIMES ASCENDING KEY IS ACCT-NO
               INDEXED BY TABLE-IDX.
               10  ACCT-NO            PIC X(8).
               10  ACCT-LIMIT         PIC S9(7)V99 COMP-3.
               10  ACCT-BALANCE       PIC S9(7)V99 COMP-3.
               10  LAST-NAME          PIC X(20).
               10  FIRST-NAME         PIC X(15).
               10  CLIENT-ADDR.
                   15  STREET-ADDR    PIC X(25).
                   15  CITY-COUNTY    PIC X(20).
                   15  USA-STATE      PIC X(15).
               10  RESERVED           PIC X(7).
               10  COMMENTS           PIC X(50).
      *
      *------------------
       PROCEDURE DIVISION.
      *------------------
       OPEN-FILES.
           OPEN INPUT ACCT-REC.
      *
       LOAD-TABLES.
           PERFORM READ-RECORD.
           PERFORM VARYING TABLE-VAR FROM 1 BY 1
             UNTIL TABLE-VAR = TABLE-MAX OR END-OF-FILE
               MOVE ACCT-FIELDS TO ACCT-TABLE-ITEM (TABLE-VAR)
               PERFORM READ-RECORD
           END-PERFORM.
      *
       SEARCH-RECORD.
           SET TABLE-IDX TO 1.
           SEARCH ALL ACCT-TABLE-ITEM
               AT END DISPLAY "Not Found"
               WHEN ACCT-NO (TABLE-IDX) = 18011809
                   DISPLAY "User with Acct No 18011809 is found!".
      *
       CLOSE-STOP.
           CLOSE ACCT-REC.
           STOP RUN.
      *
       READ-RECORD.
           READ ACCT-REC
           AT END MOVE 'Y' TO LASTREC
           END-READ.
      *

ISSUE_TEXT:
We can include a Lab with the COBOL sort verb, the lesser known COBOL counterpart to the DFSORT utility.
The INPUT PROCEDURE (for pre-processing of incoming records before the sort) and OUTPUT PROCEDURE (for post-processing of the sorted records) clauses can be used to make the sort a little more interesting.
COMMENT_TEXT: FYI, using an internal COBOL sort is not considered best practice in every commercial IT shop I've worked at (5 different shops).
COMMENT_TEXT_LEMMATIZED: fyi use an internal cobol sort be not consider good practice in every commercial -PRON- shop -PRON- have work at ( 5 different shop )

ISSUE_TEXT:
We can include a Lab with the COBOL sort verb, the lesser known COBOL counterpart to the DFSORT utility.
The INPUT PROCEDURE (for pre-processing of incoming records before the sort) and OUTPUT PROCEDURE (for post-processing of the sorted records) clauses can be used to make the sort a little more interesting.
COMMENT_TEXT: True, thanks. I think COBOL sort is less efficient than DFSORT. If we have a small enough data set to sort and need some processing before/after sort, a COBOL sort can prove convenient as we can accomplish all of it in a single program.

ISSUE_TITLE: I give up! Compile PDF is a waste of time!
ISSUE_TEXT:
After an hour and a half of trying to get the LaTex files to compile. I have decided it's just not worth the effort. There is no training worth this much hassle, just to get the lessons. It's senseless. I don't see it getter better; even if I could get the pdfs to compile.
Questions I'm left with:

how much electricity has been wasted by numerous people having to compile the pdfs, and download the supporting software?
Why not a format that's easily usable, and lightweight like HTML instead? Would that offend the open-source gods who demand fealty to the make-it-as-difficult-as-possible-so-we-feel-superior rule? Or is posting a LaTex file way more cool, and possibly impressive to the "open sores" crowd?
Why did I have to download THREE software packages I will NEVER use again, for THREE pdfs? Especially considering lightweight alternatives were easily available.
Why did the creator of this course not give one minute of thought to the user of this "course?" Was usability not even considered?
Why PDF? the idea of PDFs is to stop the end-user from  changing the info. That is NOT necessary here.

The difference between professionals and amateurs is simple. Amateurs are more worried about looking good/cool, and impressing people who really don't matter; Pros want to get things done. The same can be said about "open source" vs "professional" software.
COMMENT_TEXT:

w/Firefox, Ubuntu 14.04 w/Chrome, and Win 10 w/ Chrome and Edge.

Idle curiosity, why do you have to compile LaTex at all? Most/All distros
have it already as a package. Just 'sudo apt/yum install texlive' and Bobs
your uncle.
…
---
#include <std.disclaimer>;      | select * from users
Ed Ackerman                     |    where users.clue = 1;
edack@kengel.com                | 0 rows returned

After an hour and a half of trying to get the LaTex files to compile. I have decided it's just not worth the effort. There is no training worth this much hassle, just to get the lessons. It's senseless. I don't see it getter better; even if I could get the pdfs to compile.

how much electricity has been wasted by numerous people having to compile the pdfs, and download the supporting software?
Why not a format that's easily usable, and lightweight like HTML instead? Would that offend the open-source gods who demand fealty to the make-it-as-difficult-as-possible-so-we-feel-superior rule? Or is posting a LaTex file way more cool, and possibly impressive to the "open sores" crowd?
Why did I have to download THREE software packages I will NEVER use again, for THREE pdfs? Especially considering lightweight alternatives were easily available.
Why did the creator of this course not give one minute of thought to the user of this "course?" Was usability not even considered?
Why PDF? the idea of PDFs is to stop the end-user from  changing the info. That is NOT necessary here.

The difference between professionals and amateurs is simple. Amateurs are more worried about looking good/cool, and impressing people who really don't matter; Pros want to get things done. The same can be said about "open source" vs "professional" software.
COMMENT_TEXT:
@moueza @ClassRepo you can build the PDF but you absolutely do not need to. All releases of the course are published at https://github.com/openmainframeproject/cobol-programming-course/releases.
If you would like to contribute, feel free to just contribute to the markdown files. I create the official releases from the markdown files and will find/correct any PDF generation issues during PR review or the release creation process. The PDF is gitignored and not sourced in the repo. Git handles merge conflicts between markdown files much better than PDFs which significantly reduces the maintenance of this repo.

Simple solution to OpenMainframe Adv Challenge3.2 using only ISPF and Mainframe COBOL (non-Zowe solution) The details of this project can be found at https://github.com/openmainframeproject/cobol-programming-course A most elegant solution using Typescript to automate json to csv conversion + the Zowe API Visual Studio plugin to access the IBM sponsored mainframe - by the code master/challenger here https://medium.com/@jessielaine.punongbayan/solution-covid-19-reports-cobol-challenge-6c509579e3fe

ISSUE_TITLE: Feature: upload several files at once
ISSUE_TEXT:
Now:
$ zowe zos-files upload file-to-data-set a/aaa.cbl <USER ID>.CBL
$ zowe zos-files upload file-to-data-set b/bbb.cbl <USER ID>.CBL

Proposal:
$ zowe zos-files upload files-to-data-set a/aaa.cbl b/bbb.cbl <USER ID>.CBL

Pros:

less code
less upload time

ISSUE_TITLE: Feature: forward retcode to the output
ISSUE_TEXT:
Program:
       IDENTIFICATION DIVISION.
       PROGRAM-ID. HELLO.
       PROCEDURE DIVISION.
	   DISPLAY "Hello!".
           MOVE 1 TO RETURN-CODE.
           STOP RUN.
       END PROGRAM HELLO.

Now:
$ zowe jobs submit local-file hello.jcl --view-all-spool-content
...
Hello!
$ echo $?
0
$ zowe jobs submit local-file hello.jcl --wait-for-output --rff retcode --rft string | cut -d" " -f 2
0001

Proposal:
$ zowe jobs submit local-file hello.jcl --view-result-with-exit-code
Hello!
$ echo $?
1

Pros:

get rid of retcode parsers in CI pipelines (see Zowe tutorials with CircleCI)
single-line job submission with result and exit-code

A concern would be versioning, maybe we can add a special Translation Contributor page with the translator details (if they choose to make it public), and the version they are translating (that way people can know which version they are using).
Also in relation to that, I would say we need to indicate the version of the course for each PDF we publicize.

ISSUE_TEXT: I'm using VSCODE and working on the PAYROL0X lab, where we have to correct the picture clause to get the program to run.  I edit the PAYROL0X.cobol file, very easy, save it.  But when I submit the PAYROL0X job, it is still using the source code prior to my change.

ISSUE_TITLE: Improvement: Non-technical intro to JCL at start of course
ISSUE_TEXT:
Recently, there has been an influx of course takers that encounter the following error:
z/OSMF REST API Error:
Rest API failure with HTTP(S) status 400
rc:       4
reason:   17
category: 6
message:  Submit input data does not start with a slash

Furthermore, JCLs are crucial for submitting jobs which compile, link-edit and run their COBOL code.
Given that, I think it will be nice for us to add a short non-technical introduction to JCL, why is it necessary, etc. at the beginning of the course. Currently the first brief definition of JCL and its function are at Line 2013 of Course 1, at the ASSIGN Clause section. But by then the course taker would have submitted a few JCLs.
Maybe we can adapt the first paragraph on the IBM Knowledge Center? It doesn't have to be too in-depth, but as long as the course taker understand that JCL is there for them to run jobs which compile their code, and thus understand why they are submitting that instead of the COBOL codes, it will be great.

ISSUE_TITLE: Improvement: New Features of Enterprise COBOL v6.3
ISSUE_TEXT:
Enterprise COBOL v6.3 recently included a few new features which in my opinion will be worth exploring to include in this course, mainly the support of UTF-8 data items along with dynamic-length items.
Since our system is currently running Enterprise COBOL v6.3, it will be trivial for users to try such features on their own with the provided lab system.
If this is something which we are looking to do, I can submit a pull request for the two topic mentioned above. In any case, feedbacks are welcomed!

Cordial saludo.
Mi solicitud es para saber donde puedo descargar Enterprise COBOL v6.3 para hacer estas prácticas.
COMMENT_TEXT:
There's a Spanish translation of the course available here: https://github.com/openmainframeproject/cobol-programming-course/files/5853173/1.-.Configurando.VSCode.pdf
But to quote the translation,

Proveedores
Estos materiales están siendo utilizados por otras organizaciones para brindar capacitación
sobre COBOL a la comunidad. Ni este proyecto ni Open Mainframe Project revisan, mantienen
ni respaldan a ninguno de estos proveedores en particular. Si está utilizando estos documentos
en sus materiales de capacitación, no dude en editarlos y emitir una solicitud de extracción
para incluirlos.
- IBM ha proporcionado un entorno gratuito para completar este laboratorio. 

That will give you access to a z/OS environment with Enterprise COBOL v6.3 available.
For further assistance, do check out the #cobol-programming-course channel on the Open Mainframe Project Slack workspace.

ISSUE_TITLE: Getting started Paragraph 3.2 Basic editing: line numbers are off
ISSUE_TEXT:
In the 2.2.0 PDF COBOL-Programming-Course-1-Getting-Started.pdf in section 3.2 it refers to a file CBL0001.
It seems the file can be found as cobol-programming-course-2.2.0/COBOL Programming Course #1 - Getting Started/Labs/cbl/CBL0001.cobol in the source code zip. It would be nice if this file were hyperlinked to avoid hunting for it. While this looks like the right file by content, the line numbers specified in the guide do not match the actual line numbers of the file, which is confusing.
COMMENT_TEXT:
Hi Leo,
The lab files are not hyperlinked because they are meant to be taken on a lab system. If you haven't, you can sign up for the course's lab system at https://ibm.biz/cobollabs.
Regarding the line numbers, we are planning an update to the course which should be out in the coming months, and I'll make sure that the line numbers mentioned on the PDF match to those in the system and in the GitHub files.
Thanks for mentioning this!
